prompt: Facts: Incident occurred on October 16, 1979, at about 6:00 PM near village Saidham.; Allegation: Pappu @ Suresh Chand (Respondent-Accused), along with co-accused Nanhey, Dharampal, and Khacheru, attacked Ram Kumar (deceased) and his brother Ramesh Chand (PW-1) due to a land dispute.; Weapons allegedly used: Pappu and Nanhey used knives (chhuri); Dharampal and Khacheru used lathis.; Ram Kumar sustained knife injuries attributed to Pappu and Nanhey, and lathi injuries attributed to Dharampal and Khacheru. He died as a result.; Ramesh Chand (PW-1) sustained knife injuries attributed to Pappu and Nanhey.; First Information Report (FIR) was lodged promptly by Ramesh Chand (PW-1) at PS Kharkhoda on the same day (16.10.1979) at 7:15 PM.; Medical Examination: Dr. M.K. Jain (PW-6) examined Ramesh Chand (PW-1) on 16.10.1979 at 9:30 PM, noting incised wounds.; Autopsy: Dr. K.C. Gupta (PW-5) conducted the post-mortem on Ram Kumar's body on 17.10.1979, finding incised wounds and contusions. Cause of death was opined as shock and haemorrhage due to ante-mortem injuries.; Eyewitnesses: Prosecution relied on Ramesh Chand (PW-1, injured eyewitness), Babu Khan (PW-2), and Mahendra Singh (PW-3).; Trial Court: Convicted all four accused under Section 302 read with Section 34 IPC (sentenced to life imprisonment) and Section 324 read with Section 34 IPC (sentenced to 2 years RI). Sentences to run concurrently.; High Court: Allowed the appeal filed by the accused and acquitted all of them. Reasons for acquittal included: Doubts about the presence of PW-2 and PW-3 at the scene, finding their testimony unreliable; discrepancies in evidence; delay in the FIR copy reaching the Magistrate.; Supreme Court: State of U.P. filed an appeal against the High Court's acquittal, specifically challenging the acquittal of Pappu @ Suresh Chand. | IPC: Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 324 (Voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapons or means), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention), Section 300 (Murder - Definition, relevant for Section 302)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court erred in acquitting the accused, particularly Pappu, by discarding the credible and consistent testimony of the injured eyewitness (PW-1) and other eyewitnesses (PW-2, PW-3), which was fully corroborated by medical evidence.", "precedents": ["State of U.P. v. Kishan Chand (2004) 7 SCC 629 (Weightage to injured eyewitness testimony)", "Jarnail Singh v. State of Punjab (2009) 9 SCC 719 (Credibility of injured witness is generally higher)", "Abdul Sayeed v. State of M.P. (2010) 10 SCC 259 (Testimony of injured witness has special status)"]}, {"argument": "The High Court gave undue importance to minor inconsistencies and the alleged delay in the FIR reaching the magistrate, ignoring established legal principles that minor discrepancies do not vitiate credible testimony and procedural delays must be shown to cause prejudice.", "precedents": ["Leela Ram v. State of Haryana (1999) 9 SCC 525 (Minor variations do not affect core case)", "State of U.P. v. M.K. Anthony (1985) 1 SCC 505 (Discrepancies should not be over-emphasized if substance is consistent)", "Meharaj Singh v. State of U.P. (1994) 5 SCC 188 (Delay in FIR dispatch not fatal unless prejudice shown)"]}, {"argument": "The High Court's decision constituted perverse appreciation of evidence, justifying interference in an appeal against acquittal. The trial court's assessment was well-reasoned and based on sound evidence.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Principles for appeal against acquittal; interference if judgment is perverse)", "State of U.P. v. Ram Swarup (1974) 4 SCC 764 (Appellate court can re-appreciate evidence in appeal against acquittal)", "Allarakha K. Mansuri v. State of Gujarat (2002) 3 SCC 57 (Interference warranted if acquittal leads to miscarriage of justice)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "The High Court correctly acquitted the accused as the prosecution case suffered from material contradictions, unreliable witnesses (PW-2, PW-3), and procedural infirmities (FIR delay), creating reasonable doubt.", "precedents": ["Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras AIR 1957 SC 614 (Classification and reliability of witnesses)", "State of Haryana v. Ram Singh (2002) 2 SCC 426 (Need for caution when witnesses are partisan or interested)", "Rajeevan v. State of Kerala (2003) 3 SCC 355 (Material contradictions creating doubt)"]}, {"argument": "The presence of PW-2 and PW-3 at the scene was highly doubtful, as noted by the High Court. Their testimonies lacked credibility and were inconsistent.", "precedents": ["Kansa Behera v. State of Orissa AIR 1987 SC 1507 (Doubtful presence of eyewitnesses)", "Balaka Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1975 SC 1962 (Effect of embellishments and improvements by witnesses)", "Bihari Nath v. State of M.P. (1997) 1 Crimes 161 (SC) (Mentioned in secondary sources regarding witness presence, requires verification)"]}, {"argument": "Common intention under Section 34 IPC was not conclusively established, especially for the specific act causing death. Each accused should be liable only for their individual acts, if proven.", "precedents": ["Suresh v. State of U.P. (2001) 3 SCC 673 (Distinction between common intention and similar intention)", "Dajabhai Chagganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat AIR 1964 SC 1563 (Common intention requires prior meeting of minds)", "Mahboob Shah v. Emperor AIR 1945 PC 118 (Landmark case defining common intention)"]}]}
